etymologies: late 19th century; earliest use found in William Clark Russell (1844–1911), novelist. Probably from scrimshander, with alteration of the ending after -y

definitions: Small articles, typically of ivory or bone, decorated with engraved designs, originally produced (especially from whalebone or whales' teeth) by seamen employed on whaling ships, as a means of passing the time during long voyages; = "scrimshaw". Now only attributive in "scrimshandy work", in the same sense.
